Friday De. 13th.
no took oft tron Harenta air atrip rigat close to town in
a good old British four engined aeron operated by a company called Trans Pac. for
a 30 minute flight to ine Islea do Lino.
The herons lose money with a full load
but from a passenger point of view are quite comfortable.
"Trans. Pac" which sounas
as though it might be short for "Prana-Pacifio" ocerates only from Noumea to the
Isle de Fine.
"Dragon Rapide", a two engined Bi-plane with so many gadgets and gimmicke that we
used to say it had a "built in bead kind".
The beach at the Isle of Pines de magnificent, clean, firmly packed white
sand gently sloping towerd and into a lana locked lagoon where the water is clear
as crystal.
We are in one of ter native huts with heavily thatched roof and mat
sides but nard wood floors,
electric lights and tiled bath.
Very attractive and
right on the beach.
Its unkind to write this but we are having the kind of
weather I like- when you are never cold.
averyone dresses sensibly.
I suppose
we men are indebted to Douglas No√Ñrtaur for the open neck-no necktie style.
Practically no one wears a coat.
The Grand Pacifio Hotel in Suva suggested that
sleeved shirts.
The only ones who do not dress appropiately for the hot olimate
one wrapped around them full length with
The men wrap themselves up
in a lavu-lavu, a sort of aloth wound tightly around their waist extending below
their knees.
Dec. 14th.
1053 and shortly afterward they made it into a prison.
The temperature ranges
orime such as occured in the little town of lake George when a well intentioned
She
provided beauty reat mattresses, antle deep rugs, chintz curtains and eleotrio
blankets. A special chef provided steaks, roast beef, eto., Never has there been
such a percenta de increase in crime.
Bums came from miles around to shy a brick
through a window and then stand around tobe arrested and serve a six months
sentence.
They could get another six nonths by telling the judge they hoped when he
got home his moter would come out from under the porch and bite him. It must
have been something like that in France except that the condemned might be sent to
Devil's Island instead of here. Debby and I bave found 20 different kinds of
shells on the beach here.
Saturday afternoon, Deo, 14th. Debby and I have just returned from an ex-
parience which could only take place in Prench territory.
Yesterday there were
only a few people here but today around lunch time they started moving in from
every direction. Debby had been talking alot with a young Frenchman who has been
diving for shells ano has at least one quite valuable one. We had been talling to
him about a trip out to a reef where we might find some better suells. He suggested
et lunch time that we go out at 2:30 so at that time Deb and I went down in front
of the bentral eating place where he keeps the boat and got in expecting him to
take off right away.
The boat is about the size of Joe Barker's, perhaps 15 feet
Long with 2.45 H.P. Evinrude outboara engines.
After Debby and I waited for the
Frenohman to
leave and he cept looking shoreward expectantly, a very dizzy brunette
sot in and then a bus load of people arrived and started boarding our boat like
alot of pirates.
when they all got in, believe it or not, we counted 18 grown ups
and 9 children. If there was a life preserver on board it was not in evidence.
The
skipper could not look ahead because of the congestion on the front deck so he
stood on the funnel to spot the reefs, and there were plenty of them, reaching in
to steer the boat now and then.
We went quite a long way to a small island where'
everybody went ashore in two feet of water.
Dee. 15th.
Back in Wounea. We're getting a bit fed up with the gol darn
Prench.
They remind me alot of the Chinese- sonehow or other order eventually
flows from what appears to be utter and hopeless confusion.
This afternoon we got
